body: # Problem - The "~" eob fillchar looks very dated. - Counterargument: it's distinctive to Vim, familiar, and extremely iconic. - Counter-counterargument: Nvim's default UI needs its own subtle distinctiveness. related https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/19354 # Expected behavior - Use "middle dot" char instead of `~`. ``` set fillchars+=eob:· ``` - [Fallback](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/21710#issuecomment-1376502358) to `~` if char2cells() != 1. - Default colorscheme `EndOfBuffer` should differ from `Whitespace`. ## Notes - After using it for awhile myself, it doesn't feel garish or overwrought. It feels appropriate: it's a way to give a visual signal without demanding attention. - The "middle dot" char is already used for Nvim folds, so there's symmetry/precedent. - It feels heretical, which usually means we should do it. Compare before/after: ## Alternatives - ~~vertical ellipsis: ⋮~~ not subtle enough -

comment_data.body: I like it. One counter-argument: people who use the dot as leading whitespace char for listchars might have to adjust their setup or it could look like extra whitespace.

This actually looks quite confusing if one uses middle dot for showing whitespace.

With `:set fillchars+=eob:· list listchars+=trail:·`:

![eob](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35768171/211425606-ea69e100-320a-4e0a-b0d7-0bf46f2281b0.png)

In the picture the first four lines have a trailing space, and eob looks exactly the same as them.

I've been using it for a long time now and _much_ prefer it to the current default (admittedly, I'm also using a fairly muted highlight group for it).

(Of course, using the same symbol for two different non-text chars will be confusing, but who would do such a thing deliberately? And if you customize one, it's not a great effort to customize both (differently). For the record, I use `trail:…`.)

At the risk of starting a useless bikeshedding thread, I'll voice my opinion:  I don't understand the point of this change.

Looking at random files in GitHub, it doesn't seem to be prevalent (after scrolling for 1 or 2 minutes, it seems that `" "` is much more common): https://sourcegraph.com/search?q=context:global+file:.%2B%5C.%28vim%7Clua%29+fillchars.%2Beob&patternType=regexp&sm=1

Are we walking away from [Rule 1 of the default club](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/2676)? :)

> if you customize one, it's not a great effort to customize both

this was my reasoning.

> Looking at random files in GitHub, it doesn't seem to be prevalent

this particular case is not a case where we're chasing what's popular, rather I'm thinking about how the default UI can look better with a very small change.

> Are we walking away from [Rule 1 of the default club](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/2676)? :)

we definitely don't want to change defaults without a strong reason, but the exception to this rule is the cosmetic "first impression" of Nvim. We will change the default colorscheme for a similar reason: yes, all of this is cosmetic, but even if the result is a "wash", there is a clear net gain in that Nvim should have its own distinctive (tasteful, subtle, but distinctive) look.

if there's some other unicode char we can use, suggestions welcome.

> if there's some other unicode char we can use, suggestions welcome.

Two ideas:
- For me `eob` character should convey the "there is nothing here" message. So maybe a `⊘` or `-`? Although admittedly the first one is quite visible while second one is not that different from current default `~`.
- If "doesn't feel garish or overwrought" has more priority, a full height line `│` might be a good choice.

Two observations:
- The middle dot seems to be the most obvious choice for `space`, so using it as default for `eob` is a bit contradictory.
- Judging by the [survey result](https://gist.github.com/echasnovski/fa70dc75c475369747d2a485a13303fb#file-neovim-survey-summary_03_separated-listoptions-csv), users use either current default `~` or space.

I think `space` is a no go without `set number`.

`█` (full block) might also be worth considering. I like the idea of a symbol that is vertically continuous.
Well, dash vertical looks kinda nice 😂

@MunifTanjim nice idea. The nice thing about cosmetic stuff like this is, we can try a few things over time. Vertical dash and maybe braille dots might be worth trying.

Edit: tried them out, it's not subtle enough. Need something that mostly fades into the background.

how about using a backtick?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29005635/213161013-cd904e79-c20e-4ca3-b94d-b65a201a1d58.png)
it avoids the problem of people commonly using middle dot for trailing spaces and is pretty much the same size

Hi! This is the first time I try doing an open source contribution. I'm just grepping through a fork of the codebase and I've changed anything in the form of EOB:~ to EOB:·   . When I "make install" afterwards, it remains the same with tildes. Also my normal nvim config loads when I run the ./nvim executable in the build/bin folder. Is there something I'm missing? Thanks in advance.
I think backtick `` ` `` is a good choice for eob.

> This actually looks quite confusing if one uses middle dot for showing whitespace.

To fix that, default colorscheme can choose `EndOfBuffer` highlight that differs from `Whitespace`.
@justinmk I apologize if this is the wrong place to ask, but I would like to work on this issue. Would it be possible to be assigned to it?
er... actually please don't work on this, the last attempt was messy. I will do this myself eventually

> I think `space` is a no go without `set number`.
> 
> `█` (full block) might also be worth considering. I like the idea of a symbol that is vertically continuous.

I'm partial to `┃` (U+2503 BOX DRAWINGS HEAVY VERTICAL) although I really wish it could be made to line up with the line numbers, it would look great:

![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/38919842/ddabea21-3da4-4760-b7f3-c711d18a5663)

Oh, I just remembered years ago making a haphazard neovim patch for my own uses that lined up the eob character with the line number column, haha :sweat_smile:
I have tried a vertical line. Middle-dot is the best compromise, from my testing.

> I have tried a vertical line. Middle-dot is the best compromise, from my testing.

@justinmk, what seems important to note here is that end-of-buffer symbol should not be **too** subtle. In turn, this depends not only a symbol itself but also on its `EndOfBuffer` highlighting. As taking all color schemes into account is not really possible, the default color scheme (and maybe selection of bundled ones) should be used.

Leaving my two cents. This seems really unnecessary. `~` is already a good choice and I don't see the value in changing a setting that it is doing the job well for a potential subpart solution. 

In every text editor I ever used and in the iconography I've studied, I've always seen middle-dot used for representing whitespace and can be potentially more confusing that helpful.

> Counterargument: it's distinctive to Vim, familiar, and extremely iconic

This and `~`, at least for my experience, tends to work better across more fonts.

> Counter-counterargument: Nvim's default UI needs its own subtle distinctiveness.

I believe that the most important work in the UI department to distinguish Neovim from the rest is the default colorscheme. Witch is more apparent and more meaningful that this minor change.

title: defaults: change eob (end-of-buffer) from tilde "~" to "middle dot"
